full_title_en: ACEF II Risk Score for Cardiac Surgery
medium_description_en: Predicts 30-day mortality after elective or emergency cardiac surgery.

seo.meta_description_en: The ACEF II Risk Score for Cardiac Surgery predicts the 30-day mortality risk score for elective cardiac surgery, including emergency surgery and pre-operative anaemia risk factor.
seo.keywords_en: ACEF II Risk Score, ACEF, cardiac surgery, 30-day mortality, cardiac risk, emergency surgery, pre-op anaemia

how_to_use.use_case_en: Do you use the ACEF II Risk Score and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

next_steps.advice_en: Do you use the ACEF II Risk Score and want to contribute your expertise? Join our contributor team!

about.formula_en:
ACEF II = (A / EF) + C + Em + Hct, where variables are as follows:

Variable

Notes

A

Age, years

--

EF

Left ventricular ejection fraction, %

On most recent assessment

C

Serum creatinine, 2 points if >2.0 mg/dL (177 µmol/L); 0 if ≤2.0 mg/dL

Last recorded value before surgery

Em

Emergency surgery, 3 points if yes; 0 if no

Emergency = operation required before the beginning of the next working day after decision to operate

Hct

0.2 x (36 - hematocrit); 0 if hematocrit ≥36%

Last recorded value before surgery
about.more_info_en:
Interpetation: 

Predicted 30-day operative mortality = ex / (1 + ex)

where x = -4.86 + 0.75 x ACEF II

Original/Primary Reference.text: Ranucci M, Pistuddi V, Scolletta S, De vincentiis C, Menicanti L. The ACEF II Risk Score for cardiac surgery: updated but still parsimonious. Eur Heart J. 2018;39(23):2183-2189.

Other References.text: Barili F, Pacini D, Rosato F, et al. In-hospital mortality risk assessment in elective and non-elective cardiac surgery: a comparison between EuroSCORE II and age, creatinine, ejection fraction score. Eur J Cardiothorac Surg. 2014;46(1):44-8.

Borracci RA, Rubio M, Baldi J, Ingino CA, Barisani JL. Validation of age, creatinine and ejection fraction (ACEF) and Cockcroft-Gault ACEF scores in elective cardiac surgery. Medicina (B Aires). 2017;77(4):297-303.

creator_info.about_en: Marco Ranucci, MD, FESC, is an anesthesiologist at IRCCS Policlinico San Donato in Milan, Italy. He is also the director of clinical research for cardiothoracic and vascular anaesthesia at the IRCCS Policlinico San Donato. Dr. Ranucci’s research interests include cardiothoracic and critical care anaesthesia.
